metadata.case_name: Appellants in Civil Appeals Nos. 107, 968-971, 1185, 1168 of 1972 and Writ Petitioners in W.P. Nos. 362, 363 of 1972 v. Union of India and Ors.
metadata.case_number: Writ Petitions Nos. 362, 363 of 1972; Civil Appeals Nos. 107, 968 to 971, 1185, 1168 of 1972

facts.text: Notification under s. 4 of the Land Acquisition Act issued on November 13, 1950, stating that an area of 34,070 acres of land was needed for planned development of Delhi.
Between 1959 and 1961, about six thousand objections filed under s. 5A of the Act, which were overruled.
Declaration under s. 6 of the Act published on March 18, 1966, in respect of a portion of the area.
In 1970, notices issued under s. 9(1) of the Act requiring appellants to state objections to assessment of compensation.
Appellants challenged validity of acquisition proceedings before Delhi High Court in writ petitions filed in 1970-1971, which were dismissed on September 24, 1971 and April 17, 1971.

Influx of displaced persons in 1947 from West Pakistan into Delhi aggravated housing problem; extension of industrial, commercial activities and foreign embassies increased population without adequate housing; haphazard growth of houses; land not available at reasonable price as passed to private enterprises.
Government framed scheme for planned development of Delhi, leading to decision to acquire 34,070 acres in 1959.
Several writ petitions filed in 1966 and 1967 challenging acquisition proceedings.
Government allotted large portion of acquired land to cooperative housing societies after finalization of acquisition proceedings.
No Master Plan or Zonal Plan in existence on date of s.4 notification.
Appellants approached High Court only in 1970 when s.9 notices issued, and Supreme Court writs in 1972.

legal_issues.text: Whether the public purpose 'planned development of Delhi' specified in s.4 notification was vague, preventing effective exercise of right under s.5A.
Whether inordinate delay between s.4 notification and s.9 notices deprived appellants of benefit of appreciation in land value, violating Article 19(1)(f).
Whether s.23 of Land Acquisition Act, fixing compensation with reference to market value on date of s.4 notification, imposes unreasonable restriction under Article 19(1)(f).
Whether acquisition for planned development of Delhi could only be initiated by Central Government under s.15 of Delhi Development Act, not Chief Commissioner of Delhi.
Whether acquisition was for companies (cooperative housing societies) requiring compliance with Part VII of Land Acquisition Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: Public purpose 'planned development of Delhi' vague as no Master Plan or Zonal Plan existed, preventing effective objections under s.5A.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Land Acquisition Act ss.4, 5A; Munshi Singh v. Union of India

petitioner_arguments.text: Inordinate delay caused inadequate compensation relative to current market value when possession taken.
s.23 imposes unreasonable restriction on Article 19(1)(f) by fixing compensation date at s.4 notification regardless of delay.
Only Central Government competent to issue s.4 notification under s.15 Delhi Development Act for planned development.
Acquisition for companies (cooperative societies), so Part VII of Act required; no public funds used.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Land Acquisition Act Part VII, s.3(e)

respondent_arguments.text: Specification of 'planned development of Delhi' sufficient for large area acquisition.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Land Acquisition Act s.4; Arnold Rodricks v. State of Maharashtra

respondent_arguments.text: No inordinate delay; objections and prior writs caused time lag.
s.23 protected by Article 31(5)(a); challenge is to adequacy of compensation, precluded.
Acquisition under Land Acquisition Act valid even before Delhi Development Act plans; s.12 concerns development, not acquisition.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Delhi Development Act ss.12,15; Patna Improvement Trust v. Lakshmi Devi

respondent_arguments.text: Acquisition not for companies; allotment to cooperatives post-acquisition does not change public purpose.
Appellants guilty of laches and acquiescence in challenging s.4 notification.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Tilokchand Motichand v. H.B. Munshi; Rabindranath Bose v. Union of India

court_reasoning.text: Public purpose 'planned development of Delhi' sufficiently specified for large area; vagueness depends on facts; appellants did not raise prejudice under s.5A timely and guilty of laches.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellants approached court late after s.6 declaration; no prejudice shown in High Court.

court_reasoning.text: No inordinate delay; 6000 objections and prior writs justified time taken.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court found no delay; agreed.

court_reasoning.text: s.23 challenge barred by Article 31(5)(a) as pre-Constitution law; not procedural unreasonableness under Article 19(1)(f).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Challenge is to adequacy, precluded; interest provisions mitigate delay.

court_reasoning.text: Acquisition under Land Acquisition Act valid pre-Master Plan; s.12 Delhi Development Act concerns development post-acquisition, not acquisition itself; laches bars challenge to authority.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Government could acquire and develop with local approval.

court_reasoning.text: Acquisition for public purpose, not companies; post-acquisition allotment to cooperatives does not attract Part VII.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Funds not from cooperatives; High Court view affirmed.

court_reasoning.text: Quashing now would disturb third party rights (cooperatives).

holdings.text: s.4 notification valid; public purpose sufficiently specified.
No inordinate delay justifying higher compensation.
s.23 of Land Acquisition Act not violative of Article 19(1)(f).
Chief Commissioner could issue s.4 notification; acquisition not confined to Delhi Development Act s.15 exclusively.
Acquisition not for companies; Part VII not applicable.

precedents_cited.case_name: Munshi Singh and Others v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Necessity to specify particular public purpose in s.4 notification to enable s.5A objections; laches considered.

precedents_cited.case_name: Arnold Rodricks and Another v. State of Maharashtra and Others
precedents_cited.relevance: Specification of public purpose as 'development and utilization as industrial and residential area' sufficient.

precedents_cited.case_name: Tilokchand Motichand and Others v. H.B. Munshi and Another
Rabindranath Bose and Others v. Union of India and Others
precedents_cited.relevance: Laches and delay grounds for dismissal.

precedents_cited.case_name: R.C. Cooper v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Acquisition laws presumed reasonable if public purpose; challenge limited to procedural unreasonableness under Art.19(5).

precedents_cited.case_name: Patna Improvement Trust v. Smt. Lakshmi Devi and Others
precedents_cited.relevance: Land acquisition possible before master plan ready.

statutes_cited.name: Land Acquisition Act, 1894
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs acquisition proceedings; s.4 notification, objections, declaration, compensation date, company acquisition.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Fundamental right to property; protection for pre-Constitution laws on compensation.

statutes_cited.name: Delhi Development Act, 1957
statutes_cited.relevance: Regulates development areas and planned development; s.15 for acquisition by Central Govt.

statutes_cited.name: Land Acquisition (Amendment and Validation) Act, 1957
statutes_cited.relevance: Provides interest on compensation after 3 years from s.4 notification.

outcome.summary: The Supreme Court dismissed the writ petitions and civil appeals, upholding the validity of the land acquisition proceedings for planned development of Delhi, rejecting all contentions on merits, laches, and third party rights.

key_quotes.text: "A valid notification under s. 4 is a sine qua non for initiation of proceedings for acquisition of property. To have sat on the fence and allowed the Government to complete the acquisition proceedings... would be putting a premium on dilatory tactics."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Emphasizes laches barring challenge to s.4 notification.

key_quotes.text: "The mere fact that after the acquisition the Government proposed to hand over... a portion of the property acquired... to the cooperative housing societies would not make the acquisition one for company."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects argument that acquisition for cooperatives attracts Part VII.

key_quotes.text: "Section 23 does not deal with procedure and cannot, therefore, suffer from any procedural unreasonableness."
key_quotes.speaker: court
